title: 112_s3084
content: The Act may be cited as the "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" and pertains to the administration of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" amends Title 38 of the United States Code to establish 12 geographically defined Veterans Integrated Service Networks, ensuring alignment with the Department's mission and implementation of national goals within each network. The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" establishes 12 Veterans Integrated Service Networks to align with the Department's mission and implement national goals. Each network must maintain a regional integrated healthcare system by forming alliances with other healthcare organizations, managing a regional budget, and following Department guidelines. The Veterans Integrated Service Networks must align with Department guidelines, maintain a balanced budget, use national metrics for effective healthcare delivery, ensure high-quality clinical programs, and reduce duplicate functions. The Secretary ensures reduction of duplicate functions in the Veterans Integrated Service Networks, promotes collaboration for patient care, safety, and research effectiveness, and assesses consolidation of functions with other networks and relevant entities. The Secretary collaborates with other entities within the geographical area of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks, including offices of the Veterans Benefits Administration, Department of Defense, Coast Guard, State and local agencies, medical schools, affiliates, and offices of Congress. The Secretary ensures collaboration with various entities within the geographical area of Veterans Integrated Service Networks, including medical schools, government offices, emergency preparedness organizations, community organizations, and other relevant federal offices. Additionally, the Secretary mandates the development and sharing of innovations and best practices among the Networks at local, regional, and national levels, with each Network having only one headquarters office. The Secretary ensures each Veterans Integrated Service Network has one headquarters co-located with a VA medical center. The Secretary may employ up to 65 employees at each headquarters and must report on employment annually to Congress. The Secretary must report annually to Congress on employment at each Veterans Integrated Service Network headquarters. The report includes the number of individuals employed, their titles, and positions within the network and the Veterans Health Administration. The Secretary must conduct a triennial review of the structure and operations of Veterans Integrated Service Networks, submitting a report to Congress within 180 days. This includes assessing the impact on the Department's budget by employing individuals at the network headquarters. The Secretary must conduct a triennial review of Veterans Integrated Service Networks, assessing their structure and operations and submitting a report to Congress with recommendations for improvement. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the relevant title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must consolidate the 21 Veterans Integrated Service Networks into 12 geographically defined networks within one year of the enactment of the Act. This includes combining Veterans Integrated Service Network 1, 2, and 3 into one network, and Veterans Integrated Service Network 4 into another. Service Network 3, 4, 5, 9, 10, 11, 12, 15, and 23 will be consolidated into single Veterans Integrated Service Networks. Veterans Integrated Service Networks 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, and 22 will be combined into single networks. The consolidation of Veterans Integrated Service Networks will involve retaining one headquarters location and eliminating others to meet specified requirements. Reemployment assistance will be provided for individuals affected by the elimination of positions. The Secretary will find new employment within the Department of Veterans Affairs for individuals affected by the elimination of positions due to headquarters consolidation. Within 180 days of the Act's enactment, a plan to implement this provision must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary may relocate the Veterans Integrated Service Network headquarters to a co-located location or renew the lease for the current location. If a lease is renewed or a new lease is engaged, a report must be submitted to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary must submit a report to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs before renewing or engaging in a new lease, detailing reasons for renewal or engagement, including a list of underutilized buildings in medical centers, current lease costs, and square footage information. The Secretary must provide a report to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs before renewing or entering into a new lease, outlining reasons for the decision, including details on underutilized buildings, current lease costs, and square footage information. The report should include the cost and square footage of the current lease, as well as the cost and square footage of the new lease. SEC. 3. REGIONAL SUPPORT CENTERS FOR VETERANS INTEGRATED SERVICE NETWORKS. The Secretary shall establish up to four regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to assess the effectiveness and efficiency of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The centers will evaluate finance operations and compliance activities within the networks. The Secretary will establish regional support centers to evaluate finance operations, compliance activities, outreach to veterans of specific operations, programs for women veterans, homelessness programs, energy consumption, and other relevant matters within the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The Secretary will establish regional support centers to evaluate energy consumption and other operations of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. Staff may be hired as needed, and centers will be co-located with VA medical centers. The Secretary will establish regional support centers to evaluate energy consumption and operations of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. A report must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs before leasing a location not co-located with a VA medical center, including a list of underutilized buildings and square footage in the network. The Secretary will establish regional support centers to evaluate energy consumption and operations of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The centers will assess underutilized square footage in the network and may lease locations not co-located with a VA medical center. Initial staffing will involve transferring employees from headquarters to the regional support centers. The table of sections in chapter 73 of the title is amended to include a new item related to section 7309. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not require any changes in the location or type of medical care provided by Department of Veterans Affairs facilities.
